title: Execution gate: the last filter before you express
excerpt: Turn trading from improvisation into controlled expression. A gate protects consistency, not ego.
points: Validate structure and risk before entry style
Three fail reasons: unclear location, unclear falsification, unclear risk
Convert impulse into delay + checklist
homework: Draft your own gate: structure, falsification, risk caps, and fail rules.

title: Post-loss protocol: the 24-hour rule
excerpt: Loss is fine. The second mistake is expensive. Write a cooldown as rules to protect execution.
points: Under a loss streak, emotion takes the decision system
Cooldown is not rest—it’s review mode
Use stricter gates to avoid revenge trades
homework: Write cooldown rules for 2-loss and 3-loss streaks, plus recovery conditions.

title: Overtrading: cut the impulse chain
excerpt: Overtrading is often a lack of structure, not opportunities. Define windows and a no-trade list.
points: Decompose: trigger → action → reward
Define trading windows: express vs observe
No-trade list reduces unstructured attempts
homework: Define your windows (sessions/frequency/max orders) and a no-trade list (8+ items).

title: Trigger map before orders
excerpt: Many mistakes are not technical. They are autopilot responses. Map triggers to change execution.
points: Taxonomy: FOMO, revenge, confirmation bias, boredom trades
Two-week template: emotion, bodily cues, external stimuli
Delay 3 minutes, then run the gate
homework: Log your pre-trade state for two weeks and rank the most common triggers.

title: Regime identification before tactics
excerpt: The same tactic behaves differently across regimes. Identify first so expression has bounds and cadence.
points: Trend/range/transition: focus on participant constraints
Write direction and bounds via MTF alignment
When regime is unclear, size down or pass
homework: Use one checklist to classify EURUSD, XAUUSD, US500, and BTC.

title: Liquidity & key locations
excerpt: Location defines risk boundaries. If your stops get swept, you may be placing them in obvious spots.
points: Liquidity is not conspiracy—it’s matching mechanics
Key locations: who is forced to act, who is taking profit
Stops belong at structural falsification—not fixed distance
homework: Review last 20 stops and rewrite a better falsification point per trade.

title: Weekly breakdown report
excerpt: One report per week trains stable perception. Write bounds and falsification, not opinions.
points: Fields: regime, key locations, narrative, volatility context
Outputs: allowed scenarios + no-trade zones
Connect weekly report to gate and weekly review
homework: Write a one-page weekly report and use it daily to validate your reasoning.

title: Volatility context: parameters must adapt
excerpt: Volatility sets stop width and size. Write volatility into parameter rules to stay consistent across assets.
points: Tier markets: low/medium/high volatility
Rules: stop width, size, holding time
Impulse scaling often happens in high volatility
homework: Build a volatility tier table for your assets and write parameter adjustment rules.

title: Three-sentence method: force × location × falsification
excerpt: Write your trade in three sentences. If you can’t, you don’t have boundaries.
points: Force: impulse/pullback quality
Location: boundary and risk frame
Falsification: failure trigger and exit action
homework: Pick 10 charts and write one trade per chart using the method.

title: Falsification card
excerpt: Falsification returns you from hope back to probability. It must be triggerable, not emotional.
points: Write as: structural break / impulse failure / boundary loss
Exits are actions: trigger → execute
Clear falsification improves reviews
homework: Rewrite falsification sentences for 10 trades and review exit execution.

title: Breakout & retest
excerpt: Breakout is not the edge. Retest validity is. Express after evidence shows up.
points: Most breakout failures come from unclear location
Retest key: failure pattern presence
Use falsification to avoid chasing
homework: Collect 20 breakout cases: label retest validity and write falsification.

title: Reversal evidence chain
excerpt: Reversals are sequences: failed impulse + boundary resistance. Use sequences to avoid guessing.
points: First: impulse quality degrades, then boundary tests
Confirm via failed retest—not one big candle
In timeframe conflict: size down or pass
homework: Write your common reversal mistake as a confirmation sequence and add it to gate fail rules.
